prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus disks 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum observations of protoplanetary disk sample in Taurus, selected from VLA observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- CORRELATOR SETUP: (1) The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks. Nevertheless, we will take advantage of the spectral setup versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transition.
(2) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe the continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization in a 2000 MHz TDM mode window), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(3) Baseband 1 is split in two spectral windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines.
(4) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 spectral windows of 468.8 MHz bandwidth each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal, but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.
- IMAGING: (1) A single pointing per source is required. These targets have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 26" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.17" for MHO 1 and MHO 2; 0.10" for CY Tau; 0.13" for V892 Tau; and 0.11" for RY Tau. Hence, the C34-7 configuration is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at similar resolution than the VLA.
(3) The largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 corresponds to 3.97" (about 560~AU at the target distances). Measurements in the literature give diameters of several hundreds AU, so these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.
- SENSITIVITY: (1) Our ability to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta", which is the goal of this proposal, is predicated by achieving the necessary sensitivity in the 6.56 GHz of aggregate BW that these observations provide. The errorbar in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signa-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda 1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from the 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more. (2) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at this wavelenght. We did our best to estimate the peak flux density in the continuum from existing 1.3 mm observations presented in Harris et al. (2012), Hamidouche et al. (2010), and Isella et al. (2009). These are unresolved or barely resolved observations, so we assumed a uniform disk of emission and a typical disk diameter of 2" (or used the beam size if observations resolved the disk) to extrapolate the peak flux at the requested ALMA resolution of 0.18"
(3) In order to roughly compare to the sensitivity of our VLA observations at the ALMA frequencies, we would require sensitivities of 0.2 mJy or better with ALMA band 6. However, since we are interested in imaging substructure within these disks with ALMA, a shorter time request will hinder our uv-coverage. This will impact our ability to map faint asymmetries in the outer disk, which in turn will make difficult to constrain spatial variations of "beta".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus disks 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum observations of protoplanetary disk sample in Taurus, selected from VLA observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- CORRELATOR SETUP: (1) The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks. Nevertheless, we will take advantage of the spectral setup versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transition.
(2) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe the continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization in a 2000 MHz TDM mode window), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(3) Baseband 1 is split in two spectral windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines.
(4) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 spectral windows of 468.8 MHz bandwidth each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal, but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.
- IMAGING: (1) A single pointing per source is required. These targets have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 26" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.29" by 0.22" for UX Tau and 0.24" by 0.16" for DM Tau. Hence, the C34-7 configuration is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at similar resolution than the VLA.
(3) The largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 corresponds to 3.97" (about 560~AU at the target distances). Measurements in the literature give diameters of several hundreds AU, so these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (see Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.
- SENSITIVITY: (1) Our ability to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta", which is the goal of this proposal, is predicated by achieving the necessary sensitivity in the 6.56 GHz of aggregate BW that these observations provide. The errorbar in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signa-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from the 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(2) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at this wavelenght. We did our best to estimate the peak flux density in the continuum from existing 1.3 mm observations presented in Harris et al. (2012) and Isella et al. (2009). These are unresolved or barely resolved observations, so we assumed a uniform disk of emission and a typical disk diameter of 2" (or used the beam size if observations were resolving the disk) to extrapolate the peak flux at the requested ALMA resolution of 0.18"
(3) In order to roughly compare to the sensitivity of our VLA observations at the ALMA frequencies, we would require sensitivities of 0.2 mJy or better with ALMA band 6. However, since we are interested in imaging substructure within these disks with ALMA, a shorter time request will hinder our uv-coverage. This will impact our ability to map faint asymmetries in the outer disk, which in turn will make difficult to constrain spatial variations of "beta".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus disks 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum observations of protoplanetary disk sample in Taurus, selected from VLA observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- CORRELATOR SETUP: (1) The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks. Nevertheless, we will take advantage of the spectral setup versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transitions.
(2) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe the continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization in a 2000 MHz TDM mode window), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(3) Baseband 1 is split in two spectral windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines.
(4) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 spectral windows of 468.8 MHz bandwidth each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal, but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.
- IMAGING: (1) A single pointing per source is required as these targets have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which will fit well within the 26" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.36" by 0.26" for CQ Tau. Hence, the C34-7 configuration is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at an even better resolution than the VLA.
(3) The largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 corresponds to 3.97" (about 560~AU at the target distances). Measurements in the literature give diameters of several hundreds AU, so these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (see Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.
- SENSITIVITY:
(1) Our ability to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta", which is the goal of this proposal, is predicated by achieving the necessary sensitivity in the 6.56 GHz of aggregate BW that these observations provide. The errorbar in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signa-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from the 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(2) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at this wavelenght. We did our best to estimate the peak flux density in the continuum from existing 1.3 mm observations presented in Banzatti et al. (2011). These are barely resolved observations, so we assumed a uniform disk of emission and a typical disk diameter of 2" (or used the beam size if observations were resolving the disk) to extrapolate the peak flux at the requested ALMA resolution of 0.18"
(3) In order to roughly compare to the sensitivity of our VLA observations at the ALMA frequencies, we would require sensitivities of 0.2 mJy or better with ALMA band 6. However, since we are interested in imaging substructure within these disks with ALMA, a shorter time request will hinder our uv-coverage. This will impact our ability to map faint asymmetries in the outer disk, which in turn will make difficult to constrain spatial variations of "beta".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Ophiuchus disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum observations of protoplanetary disk sample in Ophiuchus, selected from VLA observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- CORRELATOR SETUP: (1) The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks. Nevertheless, we will take advantage of the spectral setup versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transitions.
(2) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe the continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization in a 2000 MHz TDM mode window), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(3) Baseband 1 is split in two spectral windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines.
(4) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 spectral windows of 468.8 MHz bandwidth each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal, but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.
- IMAGING: (1) A single pointing per source is required as these targets have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which will fit well within the 26" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.13" for HD142666; 0.14" for Elias 24; 0.15" for Elias 27; and 0.19" for SR24S. Hence, the C34-7 configuration is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at similar resolution than the VLA.
(3) The largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 corresponds to 3.97" (about 560~AU at the target distances). Measurements in the literature give diameters of several hundreds AU, so these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (see Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.
- SENSITIVITY: (1) Our ability to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta", which is the goal of this proposal, is predicated by achieving the necessary sensitivity in the 6.56 GHz of aggregate BW that these observations provide. The errorbar in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signa-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from the 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(2) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at this wavelenght. We did our best to estimate the peak flux density in the continuum from existing 1.3 mm observations presented in Isella et al. (2009), Ricci et al. (2012), and Natta et al. (2004). These are unresolved or barely resolved observations, so we assumed a uniform disk of emission and a typical disk diameter of 2" (or used the beam size if observations were resolving the disk) to extrapolate the peak flux at the requested ALMA resolution of 0.18"
(3) In order to roughly compare to the sensitivity of our VLA observations at the ALMA frequencies, we would require sensitivities of 0.2 mJy or better with ALMA band 6. However, since we are interested in imaging substructure within these disks with ALMA, a shorter time request will hinder our uv-coverage. This will impact our ability to map faint asymmetries in the outer disk, which in turn will make difficult to constrain spatial variations of "beta".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The first step toward planet formation is the growth of submicron grains into centimeter-sized particles inside a circumstellar disk. The long-wavelength emission from large dust is the last observable link in the growth chain from interstellar dust grains to fully fledged planets. Thus, observations of this phase provide crucial constraints to theories of early planetesimal growth and of the transport and evolution of dust particles.
In this proposal we request ALMA observations at 1.3 mm, that when combined with our existing 0.7 - 1 cm spatially resolved observations, will determine where in the disk are dust grains preferentially growing. With careful characterization of the disk thermal and density structure we can determine the dust optical depth and constrain the dust emissivity index throughout the disk. These ALMA observations will establish if spatial variations of grain growth occur in nature, as it is expected from several theoretical scenarios, like particle trapping at pressure maxima arising from vortices, turbulence, or Rossby-wave instabilities.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
